>This has nothing to do with morality,
Not OP, and not a woman, but this is very much a moral question. Morality isn't just about not doing intrinsically wrong things (like cheating), but also avoiding the *appearance* of doing them. That is, morality includes maintaining healthy boundaries, even if one's intentions aren't malicious. This is the only way that good people can behave visibly differently from the immoral. Otherwise, a guy who WOULD want to cheat could act in exactly the same way as OP's bf--being very close to another woman--and feign indignance whenever his gf/wife expresses discomfort.

While telling OP's bf that he needs to instantly cut off all contact is extreme (and if it would be justified by his actions, then OP should just break up instead, because it would have to be serious), expecting that he keep his distance from other women is an entirely reasonable baseline expectation.
Not keeping regular close contact, meeting one-on-one, or going to charged/suspicious places like bars, parties, or vacations, are all good boundaries that OP would not be wrong for trying to maintain. Her problem, from what I can see, is in her indecision and poor communication. She is panicking within the relationship but doesn't seem to have a clear idea of what she is actually willing to break up over.

Not that anon, but I'm 27 and in a similar situation as you. I only work about 5hrs a week and earn more than most of my friends combined. I have too much free time, whereas they don't. I've started going out solo to bars and clubs during the weekend and have had great success. I usually drink some vodka at home before heading out to call my nerves, and once I get to the bar/club (much easier in a bar to converse), I usually sit in a table and scope out the area. Once I finish my first drink, I approach the bar and make conversation with the bartender (can be literally about anything, this is to make it seem like you're friendly to the people around you, smile when you can and throw in a couple laughs here and there). Once I get my drink, if there's anyone near me I find attractive/approachable, I do the same thing. I just go up to them and compliment their looks, ask their opinion on something random, or just ask if I can join them and offer to pay for a round (surprisingly, this will oftentimes get you drinks paid for by them). You just have to get out there and do something. Staying couped up in your place nets you a zero percent chance of talking to someone and getting laid. At least when you step out and go to one of these places, that chance is now >0%. On days where I just wanted to wind down and sip on drinks, both women and men have come up to me and started a conversation. By simply putting yourself out there, your chances of interaction will never be 0%.

>I'm not religious either and I value monogamy
No, you don't. Monogamy, in this context, means (and it originally had this meaning exclusively) one lifetime partner. Not the watered-down "one partner at a time", which is a semantic argument away from justifying cheating as long as you're not in the same room.
And to get this true monogamy, not just in space but in time, with one's spouse, the most practical and effective way to do it is to only give yourself to a partner AFTER you've committed to staying with each other.
Also, *even if* you only value a relationship while it lasts, rather than for what it represents, waiting until marriage is STILL objectively beneficial. Those who wait, even controlling for religion, both divorce less and have happier marriages.

> Except it's not demonstrably false
Search "cohabitation effect" and see for yourself. I could post one or two studies if you really want to, but you'd probably just argue with them and accuse me of cherry-picking.

>The idea of being with one person for life, I do like.
Then you logically have to concede that waiting until you've committed to being with each other is better at getting this result than having sex first and hoping things work out. It's just a simple survivorship effect.

The rest of your last paragraph is just aimless resentment against standards. Just because you think you're above rules doesn't mean society as a whole functions better without them. If you genuinely don't need them, it won't hurt you to set a good example. But ignoring rules because you think you don't need them just lets others who are far less capable pretend the same, with negative effects for all.

As for the benefits of sexual restraint, there are a number of sources you could find (and I strongly encourage you to do at least a basic search, so you can see for yourself that this isn't cherry-picked), but here are a few examples:

http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1741-3737.2012.00996.x/abstract
>Bivariate results suggested that delaying sexual involvement was associated with higher relationship quality across several dimensions. The multivariate results indicated that the speed of entry into sexual relationships was negatively associated with marital quality, but only among women."

http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1741-3737.2003.00444.x/abstract
>"I find that premarital sex or premarital cohabitation that is limited to a woman's husband is not associated with an elevated risk of marital disruption. However, women who have more than one intimate premarital relationship have an increased risk of marital dissolution."

http://psycnet.apa.org/record/2010-25811-011
>"Both structural equation and group comparison analyses demonstrated that sexual restraint was associated with better relationship outcomes, even when controlling for education, the number of sexual partners, religiosity, and relationship length."

https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/pere.12009
>"The research objective was to test whether the number of sexual partners was associated with sexual quality, communication, relationship satisfaction, and relationship stability, while controlling for relationship length, education, race, income, age, and religiosity, using the two competing theories of sexual compatibility and sexual restraint. The results, with a sample of 2,654 married individuals, indicated that the number of sexual partners was associated with lower levels of sexual quality, communication, and relationship stability, providing support for the sexual restraint theory."

I just told you. The most practical and consistent standard to make sure you're only with your life partner, is to only have sex AFTER you've committed to being with each other.

Buy some boxes and put the stuff in them, then put the boxes somewhere out of the way and forget about them.

Eventually you'll come across them, realise you haven't thought about them or anything that's in them for months/years and getting rid of them won't be so hard.

If you're sentimental, pick a couple of special pieces to keep. Everything else goes in the boxes.

It's never too late to learn piano. It has a low skill floor with an almost infinite ceiling, meaning that there are plenty of beginner-intermediate friendly songs that you can learn without putting in an insane amount of work. OP, this is not the way to learn piano if you're solely relying on this method. Playing by ear is important by not ad important as just being able to sightread from sheet music.

Sheet music shows you the notes played and what harmonies there are + it only works with easy pieces or songs. With this shit you'll be playing rock songs yes, cause you only need like 4-6 chords max.

If you want to actually play piano (classical music) you need to just learn how to read notes and buy some sheet music.

Or if you want a specific piece/don't have lots of money to spend on this crap:
Go to the website "imslp" (International Petrucci library) which stores sheet music for a free download.

Don't switch into an antagonistic reading of this post, but you sound very whiny. You just whinge. I haven't read all your posts, but you don't even suggest a solution, a passion. I don't believe you can't hypothetically come up with a goal in life. Goals and passions don't have to be some innate quality, it can be constructed, you can "convince" yourself to regard a mild interest as a worthy goal.
The goal doesn't need to be work, education or money related. I almost feel dirty for having to point out this -- to my eyes -- self-evident rejection of a wagedrone mindset. Maybe your goal is moving to Japan, whatever.
But you don't even try to conceptualize and, blogging here, articulate a possible concrete goal.
If you can't think of one, no one can help you. Visualize your life as a trajectory: if you keep doing what you are right now, you keep doing what you are doing right now. You said you aren't happy like this. Ergo, you need to input alternate target coordinates.
Yeah yeah I know "at least others can come up with these kinds of goals as well", "I know I am not ESPECIALLY miserable, but from my perspective, the difference to a 'true/cliched' miserable state doesn't matter".
Shut up. Shut your internal monologuing. This is literally just ruminating. It accomplishes nothing. It's the hallmark of the 110 IQ word-thinker type (I am not trying to insult you). You don't NEED to monologue, or quasi-monologue by blogging here (I am not saying you should stop seeking this kind of dialogue about your problems -- or continue).
Also, I don't think what you expressed truly strikes me as ADHD (due to lack of information -- you sound like a rather generic NEET case, currently), but you might as well try to get diagnosed. I think at the very least you are such a borderline case that wouldn't need meds (especially if you don't have aspirations in very involving academic subjects), but with them you could be easily pushed over the edge to become successful.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28323697

Leadership is the ability to induce subordinates to WANT to do the right thing. A manager can order someone to run up a hill on a bright, sunny day to watch clouds.
A leader can make someone WANT TO run up a hill while being shot at with machine guns knowing the goal is to kill enough of the enemy to get the job done before they person doing the running dies.

I am quite sure you know what the other cooks *should* be doing. And I am sure you are telling them what to do.
But you aren't leading them.
Simple early steps

1) listen more than you talk. These people are more experienced at what thy do than you are. Give them a legit chance to teach you, actually learn, and find out what they think can be done better
2) That said make sure decisions are yours.
3) Never treat everyone in your team the same. Be *fair* but a hard worker that is on time and helps others can be safely trusted and just check he's ok from time to time; a slacker that needs training should be watched and helped to improve
4) Do your job and let them do theirs. 'Micromanaging' usually boils down to the manager trying to do the job and treating an employee like a tool used by the manager. This is infuriating.
5) You had better be harder working, more loyal, and more competent if you are in a high stress competitive environment. You should exhibit the same punctuality, professionalism, commitment to excellence, and so on you expect from your subordinates and they should know this without being told.
6) No one, and I mean NO ONE, "owes you" respect as a manager. Bad managers can ruin entire companies. They can shatter well-trained, highly-skilled teams. If you are put in a leadership position over a team and that team's performance drops that is ALLL YOU. If they think badly of your for hurting their performance they are correct.

Take the chip off your shoulder, stop pretending this is about your dick/lack of a dick, and either lead or leave

>>28336993
While chemo can make a cancer patient lose their appetite the tumors are often playing a much larger role in this condition. The more progressed the tumors become the less appetite the patient will have and the more they will waste away without feeling hungry.

This is a condition called cachexia (pronounced kahkexia) which is a wasting process that arises when cancer cells take advantage of the gluconeogenesis cycle. By taking advantage of the gluconeogenesis cycle, cancer cells are able to convert their lactic acid waste product (which wears down the tissues of the patient) back into glucose in the liver so it can be used by the cancer cells to create even more lactic acid in a never-ending process of destruction. Cachexia induces a state where the patient no longer feels hungry as their glucose levels are perpetually high while they continue to waste away due to lactic acid build up. Cancer cells consume glucose at about a 10x higher rate than normal cells, which is why they shine brightly on a PET scan, This heightened glucose will induce the feeling of not being hungry while the body deteriorates rapidly.

If you want to get into this topic more then I suggest starting with this post that I wrote for someone on here about two years ago. Perhaps you will find helpful as it goes into this topic a fair bit deeper:

https://pastebin.com/QrnmBqUa

>>28333061
Okay, so I fostered a kid. It's honestly not too far off regular parenting, in that it's both draining, and difficult, and miserable at times; but also rewarding.

My kid (it feels weird calling her my daughter, because she knows who her biological father is and she never called me dad, but emotionally that's what she is to me, so "my kid" is the compromise) was with me for 4 years, just moved out to go to college. One of the best things in my life was seeing how she had grown and improved from the state she came to us in.

But holy shit, it was so much work. She had tried killing herself less than 2 years before she was placed with my family, was massively behind in her education, and was frankly, just a mess. She got caught buying drugs less than a month after she moved in, and did not want to follow the rules of the household, for at least the first year. I poured more time and energy into dealing with her than I did my other two children combined. We weren't just parenting, but having to actively undo the shitty parenting that came before us.

Honestly, I wouldn't give her up for the world, but it took so much out of my wife and I, that we decided not to immediately take another foster. We need a break to recover and focus on our other children. Once our youngest is off to school, we may try it again, but we'll see.

Last year I quit for a period of a few months and then I went through a period of stress and depression and relapsed. I was never ever to stop for the rest of the year.

But last month, I started having a hard time getting an erection or cumming when I was having sex with my FWB. I had to literally think of porn while fucking her, and I thought this is so stupid. Another tip is to invest your time into something else. The first time I tried, I invested way too much time into video games. But I broke that habit. I actually end up starting a youtube and thats where I put most of energy now. You could try to find some kind of creative outlet, or just something to work on. Hell, you could even do video games; but I started feeling like I was replacing one addiction with another.

Here is all you need to know.

1. EVERYTHING created (words, pictures, music, etc) is automatically copyrighted on creation. It doesn't have to be registered or have the C-in-a-circle mark.
2. Copyright gives the creator total and absolute control over its use, commercial or noncommercial.
3. Copyright owner CAN give permission for use, but almost always will charge for it.
4. Unauthorised use can lead to you being sued into bankruptcy.

Where were your migraines expressing themselves? Over the eyes? Back of the head? Temples?
How's your sleep? Are you getting 8+ hours a night?

Anything canned with acidic foods, especially tomatoes should not be used. With your condition being as it is I would try to rule them out altogether. In this situation your endocrine has become somewhat pathological and it's probably an entire environment's worth of factors that have brought this state about.

The endocrine system is a network of organs throughout the body all of which work to maintain a hormonal homeostasis. If even one of these organs is in stress it stresses the rest of them out as well and if the environmental issues are not resolved a pathological homeostasis takes form which creates a normal state of unhealth. The problem, once this happens, is that to break an existing homeostasis requires a sharp shock to it. So you may have to make some drastic changes in order to turn things around.

Here are a few of them, there are more but these are the most important:

Vitamin D3 deficiency is a worldwide epidemic. Vitamin D is not really a vitamin, it's a prohormone and it plays myriad of roles throughout the entirety of our organism. You may want to get a blood test which tests for both the active and inactive form of vitamin D to see where your levels really are. Regardless, with most people being deficient I strongly suggest supplementing with 5000-10,000IU a day especially during the winter and the times where you're not getting sunlight. Vitamin D3 should be taken with K2 as vitamin K2 ensures that the vitamin-d associated calcium ends up where it's needed and not in the areas where it can induce trouble. As for a supplement, I recommend the Dr. Berg brand as it's the cheapest combo with U.S. made ingredients.

The liver is a secondary organ in the endocrine system but its role should not be written off. When you take NSAIDs regularly, which is particularly common for women with painful menstrual cycles, you begin to deteriorate your liver's capacity. Since you're having so many recurring migraines I can only imagine how often you rely on these to get through the day. To stop taking them is probably not an option, nor would I want you to suffer. But what you should do is chase every NSAID with at least 600mg of N-Acetyl-Cysteine, preferably Pure Encapsulations brand as they're a U.S. manufacturer that doesn't use Chinese ingredients. NAC helps replete the master antioxidant glutathione within your liver which NSAIDs rapidly deplete. Chronic use of NSAIDs will keep your liver in a perpetual state of unhealth by suppressing glutathione levels which can, over time, exacerbate and further allow this pathological homeostasis of your endocrine system to persist.

From what I'm observing based off what you have provided you are expressing multiple symptoms of estrogen dominance. This can be overcome but to break the current homeostasis requires a shock. The strongest shock you can provide, in my opinion, is fasting. I think a 3 a day water fast every month for 4-6 months might be exactly what you need to start recovering. If you are the type of person that eats three meals a day you may want to work yourself to one meal a day before going for a three day fast. To go from three meals a day to no meals a day is really difficult for people doing their first multi-day fast. You can do it, it's just more stress on the body than it would be if you were already eating one meal a day.

>>28320800

Second, you're going to want to get an intracellular magnesium and potassium test as these are the electrolytes that are most often related to estrogen dominance and glandular function. You need to specifically ask for an intracellular test for these electrolytes as they are intracellular electrolytes (98-99% are within your cells). If you rely upon a blood serum test you're not going to be able to adequately diagnose a deficiency until its in its latest stages. For some, magnesium can make migraines worse so use caution with them. I would start with magnesium glycinate and then work from there if that form of Mg induces migraines. Try to find a form of magnesium that does not stimulate migraines if you can, don't give up if the first brand/type you try induces them. For potassium I recommend buying Dr. Berg's electrolyte powder as it has 1000mg of potassium (4,700mg is the recommended daily intake) per scoop. It's the most affordable way to supplement with potassium that I have found. Most potassium in the diet comes from vegetables so you may want to try to figure out how much you need to supplement with to ensure you're meeting your dietary requirement.

Third thing you're going to want to do is clear the body out of heavy metals which you have been accumulating throughout your life. The safest way to do this is by way of Modified Citrus Pectin. 5mg/3x/day for 1 month (PectaSol / Econeugenics brand) should clear the majority of what can be cleared out minus what has been sequestered in bone of course. As a side note, I would also ditch any teflon cookware that you have and replace them with cast iron, ceramic, stainless steel or carbon steel.

Next you will need to deal with your drinking water issue. Bottled water inevitably leaches chemicals from the plastics even if it's a BPA-free plastic. I recommend dropping money on a distilled water system and adding your own trace minerals to it or using electrolyte powders to get the needed electrolytes. The brand of distiller I recommend is the My Pure Water brand:

https://mypurewater.com/shop/mini-classic-ct-distiller/

I own this one myself and it's a great machine; it's easy to maintain and only requires a once a month cleaning to keep going. If you're making soups, broths or use water for boiling to make rice/pasta then I would also invest in an undersink filter to filter out your municipal water, especially fluoride which is notorious for wreaking havoc to the endocrine system (I'll get to fluoride more in a second). The system I use is this one:

https://www.amazon.com/Frizzlife-SK99-NEW-Certified-Chlorine-Chloramine/dp/B08NDYVZV5/

As for fluoride, I would immediately stop using fluoride toothpastes. I would also be mindful of any canned foods packed in water (often packed in municipal fluoridated water) and if you can get a flouride-rated shower filter that would be helpful as well. The problem with fluoride is that it accumulates as it's readily retained at a rate of 35% - 50% of that which is ingested (younger people retaining more than adults). And when fluoride gets retained it gets sequestered in bone. The presence of iodine triggers its release and removal and there has been some brewing hypotheses regarding using iodine as a way of treating long-term fluoride toxicity.

>>28335158

No doctor, and no psychologist told you to work out, get a job and eat better as a means of dealing with depression. That simply did not happen. If you have depression and it's been ongoing for greater than 6 months, make an appointment to see a PSYCHOLOGIST not a counsellor. Commit to the therapy, invest in it and be honest with your psychologist.

Make an appointment to see your doctor as well and talk to them about getting some antidepressants to help you whilst you work through your therapy with your psychologist. This won't be a fast process, you're going to go to maybe 6-12 months of sessions. Don't stop going until the psychologist tells you to.

All of those other things won't fix depression. Depression is your mind getting stuck or fixated on a problem it is unable to resolve.

t. Almost 2 decades in medicine

"you don't know".
ok, so you have a smaller set of information to work on than you need. The next step then is ... "to know".
This is called "broadening your mind". It's the process of gathering experiences, knowledge.
It varies by individual and by culture but always involves going out into the world to gather new information. An exploration of your environment so you can "know". Many cultures have this; walkabout, journeyman.
Maybe (often) it involves travelling. Maybe it's education, though this is usually where you already "know" what you want.
When you don't know something there is always a search for information. When you don't know what you want, you first have to know what there is to want.

>>28331977
Tim Fletcher on youtube has a lot of useful videos and info. Robert Sapolsky has a ton of videos on behaivoural psychology, his video on depression being caused by fighting with yourself has been really useful.

Start keeping a diary and working on practicing cognitive restructuring and memory refactoring. Asking questions like
>What is [x] Emotion?
>When was the first time I felt [x] way?
>What does this situation remind me of?

Etc will help work through the BS. Expect the executive functioning issues to get worse before they get better. Tons of cognitive restructuring worksheets online. The memory refactoring is simpler, just know you are focusing on a congruent lifelong birth to now narrative that makes sense, and that it doesn't have to make sense to other people, just you. People naturally find hazardous memories ridiculous, it's a defense mechanism. They need you to be crazy so they don't have to deal with the idea of the possibility of the "crazy" situation happening to them complicating their lives like it has yours. Each memory, or narrative, doesn't have to be perfect, and as you remember them and add and remove details and reinterpret them and grow, you will go through the 7 stages of grief over and over and over. It's a massive pain in the ass. Only you can deal with the empirical experience in your life, other people can't. If you can work with a complex ptsd clinic all the better. I've also found Diane Langberg's speeches useful.

The biggest things you can do right now is focus on keeping your living space clean, getting a CPAP to treat sleep apnea if you're overweight, focusing on diet, and staying off drugs even if it's caffiene. Get yourself some multivitamins, magcal, vitamin C, Iron, D and Zinc and get in the habit of asking yourself at the end of the day if you had enough calcium and iron and supplimenting with that. Twinlabs has the best vitamins IMO. D and Zinc you should have on-hand to help when you get sick.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28332398
Also, You can get a MRI\Cat Scan of your brain which is how they diagnose issues these days and that might help you get on disability to have more income and funding to work with. Do note you will likely need to engage a lawyer upfront on the first disability application to help with getting it through.

BTW, regrowing your brain is likely to take years, but god is it rewarding to not have to deal with constant guilt\shame\fear, uncontrollable circular thinking, etc. It is the most exhausing thing I have personally ever done and I've put in some long fucking hours at jobs.

I used to have a messy room, and bad depression. For me, cleaning my room helped a lot. You can start bit by bit if you're too overwhelmed with the stuff. Today you can clean your bed, tomorrow maybe a corner of your room. I throw stuff away I know I'm never going to use, or you can donate them as well.

Then after you're done cleaning your room, maybe you can ask your family for therapy or something. Having an emotional support system while being at your lowest is important (I'm assuming your folks decent people and not abusive).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28332562
It happens over time in the background as you go through the cognitive restructuring.

Somedays I've worken up and realized something, other days it takes a lot of caffiene and thinking it through. Some days are easy, others are really hard. And there's a lot of repetition of the same things over and over especially where it comes to perceptional templates or schema's, which are basically things your parents or society tought you that you take for assumptions. E.G. My mother didn't have the concept of being loved until she had children, then she got that concept of unconditional love from the baby and didn't let us form boundaries early on, and that fucked up my head. Those kinds of things are a real bitch.

Like you wake up and realize all of the standards the specific society you are in are bullshit because the people producing the standards, statistically, have not experienced a single traumatic event in their families. You remember times of going to the hospital with your parent after they were gravely injured and seeing a family huddled and praying around their elderly, and recognize that for what it is; people who are functional enough to form social bonds. These are the yuppie freaks of nature, they have no appreciation for the history they have come from because putting themselves in the shoes of their ancestors seems so far fetched. 50% of all people born never made it to the age of 18, death used to be everywhere, and these people have no concept of that and for them to understand that requires they grow as a person in ways that are not obvious to them now. They take their days for granted.

Over time, you heal, and stop being in such dire straights. Best part is once you've gotten out of the morass your perception is way, way better than the average persons, and you enjoy the little things in life more.

Just doing the cognitive restructuring causes the brain to grow, and it is by far the most exhausting thing I've ever done.

Once you are there, do not, I repeat DO NOT be alone with a kid in any circumstance, it's fine to play with the children but not too much (it's better if you don't actually), and do not expect or initiate an act of hugging (or any other intimacy).

Do not explicitly say you think they are wrong or say anything about "people who think like them", just bring up counter points, as if you are innocently questioning their ideas, or as if trying to think the better way to think like them (something like: "I think these are bigots"; "yeah this might be true, but why exactly"). The "should i try lsd quick guide":

1. Is there any history of psychotic disorders in yojr family? Schizophrenia, borderline, bipolar, anything that involves episodes of losing touch with reality?
If yes: psychedelics arent for you. Give it a miss.

2. If you are scared to face your worst demons, like youre one to ignore deny or pretend your insecurities dont exist, theyll all hit you in the face like a bag of bricks and you wont be able to handle it. Its not for you. Give it a miss.

3. If you are a curious open individual, can handle facing yourself if it comes up, youre able to relax and let go of shit, youd be fine. But make aure you do a lot of reading First. Know what to expect.

>it can be the best or worst experience

Heres the thing with it. Its a mood enhancer. Anything you think or feel gets multiplied while on lsd. If you think youre having fun, its rhe best time kf your life. If you think youre dying or slipping into an evil dimension, itll overcome you.
The good news is, you have quite a lot ot control. If you hust accept whats happening, chill, let things go as they do, and redirect yohr attention if things go sideways, youll be fine.

Also sometimes a bad trip, where, say, youre realizing what an asshole you are to everyone or suddenly start unpacking childhood trauma: Not necessarily a bad thing. You can learn and grow a lot with these experiences if youre able to not have a meltdown.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28335098
You cant overdose on lsd, and because of its mechanism it wont fry you either. Worst case scenario youll black out.
To be more specific with what i mentioned here>>28335166

The main fears with lsd are that jf you have an underlying psychotic disorder, lsd can activate it (alcohol, weed, and traumatic experiences can do the same though so it isnt unique in that respect) and the other is that if you have a really bad trip and you cant handle it, it can be traumatizing the same way a terrifying experience without lsd can be traumatizing. Nothing the lsd itself is doing, just the fact that scary experiences can really mess with our neurology, and plasticity is high while on psychadelics. But you can innoculate yourself against the latter by just knowing nothing bad can actually happen, youll be fine, the trip ends, and you can just change the song or have a drink to put the trip back on track

>>28334850
I think if you're curious about the experience that you probably couldn't go wrong with taking a single tab, but LSD trips are very long and certainly aren't the first drug I'd recommend to someone who has little to no experience with them.
Regardless, I'd say you should definitely keep them for the time being. They have an extremely long shelf life so long as you keep them in a dark, cool environment, and they don't have an odor; nobody would ever find them unless someone specifically sent the cops after you for some reason.
Even if you don't want to try them yourself, you might meet a person that has some interest in them that would probably greatly appreciate a free hit or two of acid. You could also offer to hang out with your friend while he takes some of the LSD, as strange as that might sound. He would probably be very flattered by that.
If you keep them and plan to use them responsibly, ten hits of LSD could very well be a lifetime supply.

too young, don't take it. Give it back to your friend and tell them you're not ready. If there's any doubt then you shouldn't do it. Seriously. The best time to take psychedelics is when you're feeling safe, you're around people you trust, and you don't have an ounce of doubt in your mind. Otherwise, and especially when you're the anxious type, that doubt risks being the negative energy you will focus on to turn it into a bad time.

Acid isn't a bad drug. The idea that mushrooms are somehow better cause they're natural is a myth. I don't know what it is, but something about acid keeps you reeled in and knowing that what you're experiencing is all just a symptom of the drug and makes it much easier to ride it out and experience everything from like a safe distance. Mushrooms twists your mind and makes you see and realise things that you can't go back on or have distance from. At least that's my experience, taking them under the age of 25.
